an3.67:1.1.eng: “There are, mendicants, these three topics of discussion.

an3.67:1.3.pli: Atītaṃ vā, bhikkhave, addhānaṃ ārabbha kathaṃ katheyya:

an3.67:1.4.eng: ‘That is how it was in the past.’

an3.67:1.5.pli: Anāgataṃ vā, bhikkhave, addhānaṃ ārabbha kathaṃ katheyya:

an3.67:1.6.eng: ‘That is how it will be in the future.’

an3.67:1.7.pli: Etarahi vā, bhikkhave, paccuppannaṃ addhānaṃ ārabbha kathaṃ katheyya:
an3.67:1.7.eng: Or you might discuss the present:

an3.67:1.8.eng: ‘This is how it is at present.’

an3.67:2.1.pli: Kathāsampayogena, bhikkhave, puggalo veditabbo yadi vā kaccho yadi vā akacchoti.
an3.67:2.1.eng: You can know whether or not an individual is competent to hold a discussion by seeing how they take part in a discussion.

an3.67:2.2.pli: Sacāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo pañhaṃ puṭṭho samāno ekaṃsabyākaraṇīyaṃ pañhaṃ na ekaṃsena byākaroti, vibhajjabyākaraṇīyaṃ pañhaṃ na vibhajja byākaroti, paṭipucchābyākaraṇīyaṃ pañhaṃ na paṭipucchā byākaroti, ṭhapanīyaṃ pañhaṃ na ṭhapeti, evaṃ santāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo akaccho hoti.
an3.67:2.2.eng: When an individual is asked a question, if it needs to be answered categorically and they don’t answer it categorically; or if it needs analysis and they answer without analyzing it; or if it needs a counter-question and they answer without a counter-question; or if it should be set aside and they don’t set it aside, then that individual is not competent to hold a discussion.

an3.67:2.3.pli: Sace panāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo pañhaṃ puṭṭho samāno ekaṃsabyākaraṇīyaṃ pañhaṃ ekaṃsena byākaroti, vibhajjabyākaraṇīyaṃ pañhaṃ vibhajja byākaroti, paṭipucchābyākaraṇīyaṃ pañhaṃ paṭipucchā byākaroti, ṭhapanīyaṃ pañhaṃ ṭhapeti, evaṃ santāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo kaccho hoti.
an3.67:2.3.eng: When an individual is asked a question, if it needs to be answered categorically and they answer it categorically; or if it needs analysis and they answer after analyzing it; or if it needs a counter-question and they answer with a counter-question; or if it should be set aside and they set it aside, then that individual is competent to hold a discussion.

an3.67:3.1.pli: Kathāsampayogena, bhikkhave, puggalo veditabbo yadi vā kaccho yadi vā akacchoti.
an3.67:3.1.eng: You can know whether or not an individual is competent to hold a discussion by seeing how they take part in a discussion.

an3.67:3.2.pli: Sacāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo pañhaṃ puṭṭho samāno ṭhānāṭhāne na saṇṭhāti parikappe na saṇṭhāti aññātavāde na saṇṭhāti paṭipadāya na saṇṭhāti, evaṃ santāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo akaccho hoti.
an3.67:3.2.eng: When an individual is asked a question, if they’re not consistent about what their position is and what it isn’t; about what they propose; about speaking from what they know; and about the appropriate procedure, then that individual is not competent to hold a discussion.

an3.67:3.3.pli: Sace panāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo pañhaṃ puṭṭho samāno ṭhānāṭhāne saṇṭhāti parikappe saṇṭhāti aññātavāde saṇṭhāti paṭipadāya saṇṭhāti, evaṃ santāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo kaccho hoti.
an3.67:3.3.eng: When an individual is asked a question, if they are consistent about what their position is and what it isn’t; about what they propose; about speaking from what they know; and about the appropriate procedure, then that individual is competent to hold a discussion.

an3.67:4.1.pli: Kathāsampayogena, bhikkhave, puggalo veditabbo yadi vā kaccho yadi vā akacchoti.
an3.67:4.1.eng: You can know whether or not an individual is competent to hold a discussion by seeing how they take part in a discussion.

an3.67:4.2.pli: Sacāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo pañhaṃ puṭṭho samāno aññenaññaṃ paṭicarati, bahiddhā kathaṃ apanāmeti, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti, evaṃ santāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo akaccho hoti.
an3.67:4.2.eng: When an individual is asked a question, if they dodge the issue; distract the discussion with irrelevant points; or display annoyance, hate, and bitterness, then that individual is not competent to hold a discussion.

an3.67:4.3.pli: Sace panāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo pañhaṃ puṭṭho samāno na aññenaññaṃ paṭicarati na bahiddhā kathaṃ apanāmeti, na kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti, evaṃ santāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo kaccho hoti.
an3.67:4.3.eng: When an individual is asked a question, if they don’t dodge the issue; distract the discussion with irrelevant points; or display annoyance, hate, and bitterness, then that individual is competent to hold a discussion.

an3.67:5.1.pli: Kathāsampayogena, bhikkhave, puggalo veditabbo yadi vā kaccho yadi vā akacchoti.
an3.67:5.1.eng: You can know whether or not an individual is competent to hold a discussion by seeing how they take part in a discussion.

an3.67:5.2.pli: Sacāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo pañhaṃ puṭṭho samāno abhiharati abhimaddati anupajagghati khalitaṃ gaṇhāti, evaṃ santāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo akaccho hoti.
an3.67:5.2.eng: When an individual is asked a question, if they intimidate, crush, mock, or seize on trivial mistakes, then that individual is not competent to hold a discussion.

an3.67:5.3.pli: Sace panāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo pañhaṃ puṭṭho samāno nābhiharati nābhimaddati na anupajagghati na khalitaṃ gaṇhāti, evaṃ santāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo kaccho hoti.
an3.67:5.3.eng: When an individual is asked a question, if they don’t intimidate, crush, mock, or seize on trivial mistakes, then that individual is competent to hold a discussion.

an3.67:6.1.pli: Kathāsampayogena, bhikkhave, puggalo veditabbo yadi vā saupaniso yadi vā anupanisoti.
an3.67:6.1.eng: You can know whether or not an individual has what’s required by seeing how they take part in a discussion.

an3.67:6.2.pli: Anohitasoto, bhikkhave, anupaniso hoti, ohitasoto saupaniso hoti.
an3.67:6.2.eng: If they actively listen they have what’s required; if they don’t actively listen they don’t have what’s required.

an3.67:6.3.pli: So saupaniso samāno abhijānāti ekaṃ dhammaṃ, parijānāti ekaṃ dhammaṃ, pajahati ekaṃ dhammaṃ, sacchikaroti ekaṃ dhammaṃ.
an3.67:6.3.eng: Someone who has what’s required directly knows one thing, completely understands one thing, gives up one thing, and realizes one thing—

an3.67:6.4.pli: So abhijānanto ekaṃ dhammaṃ, parijānanto ekaṃ dhammaṃ, pajahanto ekaṃ dhammaṃ, sacchikaronto ekaṃ dhammaṃ sammāvimuttiṃ phusati.
an3.67:6.4.eng: and then they experience complete freedom.

an3.67:6.5.eng: This is the purpose of discussion,

an3.67:6.8.pli: etadatthaṃ sotāvadhānaṃ, yadidaṃ anupādā cittassa vimokkhoti.
an3.67:6.8.eng: and listening well, that is, the liberation of the mind by not grasping.

an3.67:7.4.eng: they look for flaws in each other.

an3.67:8.1.eng: They rejoice together when their opponent

an3.67:8.2.eng: speaks poorly and makes a mistake,

an3.67:8.4.eng: but the noble ones don’t discuss like this.

an3.67:9.1.eng: If an astute person wants to hold a discussion

an3.67:9.2.eng: connected with the teaching and its meaning—

an3.67:9.3.eng: the kind of discussion that noble ones hold—

an3.67:9.4.eng: then that wise one should start the discussion,

an3.67:10.1.eng: knowing when the time is right,

an3.67:11.1.eng: or with a mind full of jealousy,

an3.67:11.2.eng: they’d speak from what they rightly know.

an3.67:11.3.eng: They agree with what was well spoken,

an3.67:11.4.eng: without criticizing what was poorly said.

an3.67:12.1.eng: They’d not persist in finding faults,

an3.67:12.3.eng: neither intimidating nor crushing the other,

an3.67:13.2.eng: for the sake of knowledge and clarity.

an3.67:13.3.eng: That’s how the noble ones consult,

an3.68:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, if wanderers of other religions were to ask:

an3.68:1.6.pli: Imesaṃ, āvuso, tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ ko viseso ko adhippayāso kiṃ nānākaraṇan’ti?

an3.68:1.7.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ kinti byākareyyāthā”ti?

an3.68:1.8.pli: “Bhagavaṃmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā bhagavaṃnettikā bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā. Sādhu vata, bhante, bhagavantaṃyeva paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
an3.68:1.8.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

an3.68:1.9.pli: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
an3.68:1.9.eng: “Well then, mendicants, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an3.68:1.10.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

an3.68:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, if wanderers of other religions were to ask:

an3.68:2.6.pli: imesaṃ, āvuso, tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ ko viseso ko adhippayāso kiṃ nānākaraṇan’ti?

an3.68:2.7.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyātha:

an3.68:2.8.pli: ‘rāgo kho, āvuso, appasāvajjo dandhavirāgī, doso mahāsāvajjo khippavirāgī, moho mahāsāvajjo dandhavirāgī’ti.
an3.68:2.8.eng: ‘Greed, reverends, is mildly blameworthy, but slow to fade away. Hate is very blameworthy, but quick to fade away. Delusion is very blameworthy, and slow to fade away.’

an3.68:3.1.pli: ‘Ko panāvuso, hetu ko paccayo yena anuppanno vā rāgo uppajjati uppanno vā rāgo bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya saṃvattatī’ti?
an3.68:3.1.eng: And if they ask: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why greed arises, and once arisen it increases and grows?’

an3.68:3.2.eng: You should say: ‘The beautiful feature of things.

an3.68:3.3.pli: Tassa subhanimittaṃ ayoniso manasi karoto anuppanno vā rāgo uppajjati uppanno vā rāgo bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya saṃvattati.
an3.68:3.3.eng: When you apply the mind irrationally to the beautiful feature of things, greed arises, and once arisen it increases and grows.

an3.68:3.4.pli: Ayaṃ kho, āvuso, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yena anuppanno vā rāgo uppajjati uppanno vā rāgo bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya saṃvattatī’ti.
an3.68:3.4.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why greed arises, and once arisen it increases and grows.’

an3.68:4.1.pli: ‘Ko panāvuso, hetu ko paccayo yena anuppanno vā doso uppajjati uppanno vā doso bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya saṃvattatī’ti?
an3.68:4.1.eng: And if they ask: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why hate arises, and once arisen it increases and grows?’

an3.68:4.2.eng: You should say: ‘The feature of harshness.

an3.68:4.3.pli: Tassa paṭighanimittaṃ ayoniso manasi karoto anuppanno vā doso uppajjati uppanno vā doso bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya saṃvattati.
an3.68:4.3.eng: When you apply the mind irrationally to the feature of harshness, hate arises, and once arisen it increases and grows.

an3.68:4.4.pli: Ayaṃ kho, āvuso, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yena anuppanno vā doso uppajjati uppanno vā doso bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya saṃvattatī’ti.
an3.68:4.4.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why hate arises, and once arisen it increases and grows.’

an3.68:5.1.pli: ‘Ko panāvuso, hetu ko paccayo yena anuppanno vā moho uppajjati uppanno vā moho bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya saṃvattatī’ti?
an3.68:5.1.eng: And if they ask: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why delusion arises, and once arisen it increases and grows?’

an3.68:5.2.eng: You should say: ‘Irrational application of mind.

an3.68:5.3.pli: Tassa ayoniso manasi karoto anuppanno vā moho uppajjati uppanno vā moho bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya saṃvattati.
an3.68:5.3.eng: When you apply the mind irrationally, delusion arises, and once arisen it increases and grows.

an3.68:5.4.pli: Ayaṃ kho, āvuso, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yena anuppanno vā moho uppajjati uppanno vā moho bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya saṃvattatī’ti.
an3.68:5.4.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why delusion arises, and once arisen it increases and grows.’

an3.68:6.1.pli: ‘Ko panāvuso, hetu ko paccayo yena anuppanno ceva rāgo nuppajjati uppanno ca rāgo pahīyatī’ti?
an3.68:6.1.eng: And if they ask, ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why greed doesn’t arise, or if it’s already arisen it’s given up?’

an3.68:6.2.eng: You should say: ‘The ugly feature of things.

an3.68:6.3.pli: Tassa asubhanimittaṃ yoniso manasi karoto anuppanno ceva rāgo nuppajjati uppanno ca rāgo pahīyati.
an3.68:6.3.eng: When you apply the mind rationally on the ugly feature of things, greed doesn’t arise, or if it’s already arisen it’s given up.

an3.68:6.4.pli: Ayaṃ kho, āvuso, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yena anuppanno ceva rāgo nuppajjati uppanno ca rāgo pahīyatī’ti.
an3.68:6.4.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why greed doesn’t arise, or if it’s already arisen it’s given up.’

an3.68:7.1.pli: ‘Ko panāvuso, hetu ko paccayo yena anuppanno ceva doso nuppajjati uppanno ca doso pahīyatī’ti?
an3.68:7.1.eng: And if they ask, ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why hate doesn’t arise, or if it’s already arisen it’s given up?’

an3.68:7.2.eng: You should say: ‘The heart’s release by love.’

an3.68:7.3.pli: Tassa mettaṃ cetovimuttiṃ yoniso manasi karoto anuppanno ceva doso nuppajjati uppanno ca doso pahīyati.
an3.68:7.3.eng: When you apply the mind rationally on the heart’s release by love, hate doesn’t arise, or if it’s already arisen it’s given up.

an3.68:7.4.pli: Ayaṃ kho, āvuso, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yena anuppanno ceva doso nuppajjati uppanno ca doso pahīyatī’ti.
an3.68:7.4.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why hate doesn’t arise, or if it’s already arisen it’s given up.’

an3.68:8.1.pli: ‘Ko panāvuso, hetu ko paccayo yena anuppanno ceva moho nuppajjati uppanno ca moho pahīyatī’ti?
an3.68:8.1.eng: And if they ask, ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why delusion doesn’t arise, or if it’s already arisen it’s given up?’

an3.68:8.2.eng: You should say: ‘Rational application of mind.

an3.68:8.3.pli: Tassa yoniso manasi karoto anuppanno ceva moho nuppajjati uppanno ca moho pahīyati.
an3.68:8.3.eng: When you apply the mind rationally, delusion doesn’t arise, or if it’s already arisen it’s given up.

an3.68:8.4.pli: Ayaṃ kho, āvuso, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yena anuppanno vā moho nuppajjati uppanno ca moho pahīyatī’”ti.
an3.68:8.4.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why delusion doesn’t arise, or if it’s already arisen it’s given up.’”

an3.69:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these three unskillful roots.

an3.69:1.3.pli: Lobho akusalamūlaṃ, doso akusalamūlaṃ, moho akusalamūlaṃ.

an3.69:2.1.eng: Greed is a root of the unskillful.

an3.69:2.2.pli: yadapi luddho abhisaṅkharoti kāyena vācāya manasā tadapi akusalaṃ;
an3.69:2.2.eng: When a greedy person chooses to act by way of body, speech, or mind, that too is unskillful.

an3.69:2.3.pli: yadapi luddho lobhena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto parassa asatā dukkhaṃ uppādayati vadhena vā bandhanena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā pabbājanāya vā balavamhi balattho itipi tadapi akusalaṃ.
an3.69:2.3.eng: When a greedy person, overcome by greed, causes another to suffer under a false pretext—by execution or imprisonment or confiscation or condemnation or banishment—thinking ‘I’m powerful, I want power’, that too is unskillful.

an3.69:2.4.pli: Itissame lobhajā lobhanidānā lobhasamudayā lobhapaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti.
an3.69:2.4.eng: And so these many bad, unskillful things are produced in them, born, sourced, originated, and conditioned by greed.

an3.69:3.1.eng: Hate is a root of the unskillful.

an3.69:3.2.pli: yadapi duṭṭho abhisaṅkharoti kāyena vācāya manasā tadapi akusalaṃ;
an3.69:3.2.eng: When a hateful person chooses to act by way of body, speech, or mind, that too is unskillful.

an3.69:3.3.pli: yadapi duṭṭho dosena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto parassa asatā dukkhaṃ uppādayati vadhena vā bandhanena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā pabbājanāya vā balavamhi balattho itipi tadapi akusalaṃ.
an3.69:3.3.eng: When a hateful person, overcome by hate, causes another to suffer under a false pretext—by execution or imprisonment or confiscation or condemnation or banishment—thinking ‘I’m powerful, I want power’, that too is unskillful.

an3.69:3.4.pli: Itissame dosajā dosanidānā dosasamudayā dosapaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti.
an3.69:3.4.eng: And so these many bad, unskillful things are produced in them, born, sourced, originated, and conditioned by hate.

an3.69:4.1.eng: Delusion is a root of the unskillful.

an3.69:4.2.pli: yadapi mūḷho abhisaṅkharoti kāyena vācāya manasā tadapi akusalaṃ;
an3.69:4.2.eng: When a deluded person chooses to act by way of body, speech, or mind, that too is unskillful.

an3.69:4.3.pli: yadapi mūḷho mohena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto parassa asatā dukkhaṃ uppādayati vadhena vā bandhanena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā pabbājanāya vā balavamhi balattho itipi tadapi akusalaṃ.
an3.69:4.3.eng: When a deluded person, overcome by delusion, causes another to suffer under a false pretext—by execution or imprisonment or confiscation or condemnation or banishment—thinking ‘I’m powerful, I want power’, that too is unskillful.

an3.69:4.4.pli: Itissame mohajā mohanidānā mohasamudayā mohapaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti.
an3.69:4.4.eng: And so these many bad, unskillful things are produced in them, born, sourced, originated, and conditioned by delusion.

an3.69:4.5.pli: Evarūpo cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo vuccati akālavādītipi, abhūtavādītipi, anatthavādītipi, adhammavādītipi, avinayavādītipi.
an3.69:4.5.eng: Such an individual is said to have speech that’s ill-timed, false, meaningless, not in line with the teaching and training.

an3.69:5.1.pli: Kasmā cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, evarūpo puggalo vuccati akālavādītipi, abhūtavādītipi, anatthavādītipi, adhammavādītipi, avinayavādītipi?

an3.69:5.2.pli: Tathāhāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo parassa asatā dukkhaṃ uppādayati vadhena vā bandhanena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā pabbājanāya vā balavamhi balattho itipi.
an3.69:5.2.eng: This individual causes another to suffer under a false pretext—by execution or imprisonment or confiscation or condemnation or banishment—thinking ‘I’m powerful, I want power’.

an3.69:5.3.pli: Bhūtena kho pana vuccamāno avajānāti, no paṭijānāti;
an3.69:5.3.eng: So when someone makes a valid criticism, they’re scornful and admit nothing.

an3.69:5.4.pli: abhūtena vuccamāno na ātappaṃ karoti, tassa nibbeṭhanāya itipetaṃ atacchaṃ itipetaṃ abhūtanti.
an3.69:5.4.eng: When someone makes a baseless criticism, they make no effort to explain, ‘This is why that’s untrue, this is why that’s false.’

an3.69:5.5.pli: Tasmā evarūpo puggalo vuccati akālavādītipi, abhūtavādītipi, anatthavādītipi, adhammavādītipi, avinayavādītipi.
an3.69:5.5.eng: That’s why such an individual is said to have speech that’s ill-timed, false, meaningless, not in line with the teaching and training.

an3.69:6.1.pli: Evarūpo, bhikkhave, puggalo lobhajehi pāpakehi akusalehi dhammehi abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto diṭṭhe ceva dhamme dukkhaṃ viharati, savighātaṃ saupāyāsaṃ sapariḷāhaṃ.
an3.69:6.1.eng: Such an individual—overcome with bad, unskillful qualities born of greed, hate, and delusion—suffers in this very life, with distress, anguish, and fever.

an3.69:6.2.pli: Kāyassa ca bhedā paraṃ maraṇā duggati pāṭikaṅkhā.
an3.69:6.2.eng: And when the body breaks up, after death, they can expect to be reborn in a bad place.

an3.69:7.2.pli: mohajehi pāpakehi akusalehi dhammehi abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto diṭṭhe ceva dhamme dukkhaṃ viharati, savighātaṃ saupāyāsaṃ sapariḷāhaṃ.

an3.69:7.3.pli: Kāyassa ca bhedā paraṃ maraṇā duggati pāṭikaṅkhā.

an3.69:7.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, sālo vā dhavo vā phandano vā tīhi māluvālatāhi uddhasto pariyonaddho anayaṃ āpajjati, byasanaṃ āpajjati, anayabyasanaṃ āpajjati;
an3.69:7.4.eng: Suppose a sal, axlewood, or boxwood tree was choked and engulfed by three camel’s foot creepers. It would fall to ruin and disaster.

an3.69:7.5.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, evarūpo puggalo lobhajehi pāpakehi akusalehi dhammehi abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto diṭṭhe ceva dhamme dukkhaṃ viharati, savighātaṃ saupāyāsaṃ sapariḷāhaṃ.
an3.69:7.5.eng: In the same way, such an individual—overcome with bad, unskillful qualities born of greed, hate, and delusion—suffers in this very life, with distress, anguish, and fever.

an3.69:7.6.pli: Kāyassa ca bhedā paraṃ maraṇā duggati pāṭikaṅkhā.
an3.69:7.6.eng: And when the body breaks up, after death, they can expect to be reborn in a bad place.

an3.69:8.2.pli: mohajehi pāpakehi akusalehi dhammehi abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto diṭṭhe ceva dhamme dukkhaṃ viharati savighātaṃ saupāyāsaṃ sapariḷāhaṃ.

an3.69:8.3.pli: Kāyassa ca bhedā paraṃ maraṇā duggati pāṭikaṅkhā.

an3.69:8.4.eng: These are the three unskillful roots.

an3.69:9.1.eng: There are these three skillful roots.

an3.69:9.3.pli: Alobho kusalamūlaṃ, adoso kusalamūlaṃ, amoho kusalamūlaṃ.

an3.69:10.1.eng: Contentment is a root of the skillful.

an3.69:10.2.pli: yadapi aluddho abhisaṅkharoti kāyena vācāya manasā tadapi kusalaṃ;
an3.69:10.2.eng: When a contented person chooses to act by way of body, speech, or mind, that too is skillful.

an3.69:10.3.pli: yadapi aluddho lobhena anabhibhūto apariyādinnacitto na parassa asatā dukkhaṃ uppādayati vadhena vā bandhanena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā pabbājanāya vā balavamhi balattho itipi tadapi kusalaṃ.
an3.69:10.3.eng: When a contented person, not overcome by greed, doesn’t cause another to suffer under a false pretext—by execution or imprisonment or confiscation or condemnation or banishment—thinking ‘I’m powerful, I want power’, that too is skillful.

an3.69:10.4.pli: Itissame alobhajā alobhanidānā alobhasamudayā alobhapaccayā aneke kusalā dhammā sambhavanti.
an3.69:10.4.eng: And so these many skillful things are produced in them, born, sourced, originated, and conditioned by contentment.

an3.69:11.1.eng: Love is a root of the skillful.

an3.69:11.2.pli: yadapi aduṭṭho abhisaṅkharoti kāyena vācāya manasā tadapi kusalaṃ;
an3.69:11.2.eng: When a loving person chooses to act by way of body, speech, or mind, that too is skillful.

an3.69:11.3.pli: yadapi aduṭṭho dosena anabhibhūto apariyādinnacitto na parassa asatā dukkhaṃ uppādayati vadhena vā bandhanena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā pabbājanāya vā balavamhi balattho itipi tadapi kusalaṃ.
an3.69:11.3.eng: When a loving person, not overcome by hate, doesn’t cause another to suffer under a false pretext—by execution or imprisonment or confiscation or condemnation or banishment—thinking ‘I’m powerful, I want power’, that too is skillful.

an3.69:11.4.pli: Itissame adosajā adosanidānā adosasamudayā adosapaccayā aneke kusalā dhammā sambhavanti.
an3.69:11.4.eng: And so these many skillful things are produced in them, born, sourced, originated, and conditioned by love.

an3.69:12.1.eng: Understanding is a root of the skillful.

an3.69:12.2.pli: yadapi amūḷho abhisaṅkharoti kāyena vācāya manasā tadapi kusalaṃ;
an3.69:12.2.eng: When an understanding person chooses to act by way of body, speech, or mind, that too is skillful.

an3.69:12.3.pli: yadapi amūḷho mohena anabhibhūto apariyādinnacitto na parassa asatā dukkhaṃ uppādayati vadhena vā bandhanena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā pabbājanāya vā balavamhi balattho itipi tadapi kusalaṃ.
an3.69:12.3.eng: When an understanding person, not overcome by delusion, doesn’t cause another to suffer under a false pretext—by execution or imprisonment or confiscation or condemnation or banishment—thinking ‘I’m powerful, I want power’, that too is skillful.

an3.69:12.4.pli: Itissame amohajā amohanidānā amohasamudayā amohapaccayā aneke kusalā dhammā sambhavanti.
an3.69:12.4.eng: And so these many skillful things are produced in them, born, sourced, originated, and conditioned by understanding.

an3.69:12.5.pli: Evarūpo cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo vuccati kālavādītipi, bhūtavādītipi, atthavādītipi, dhammavādītipi, vinayavādītipi.
an3.69:12.5.eng: Such an individual is said to have speech that’s well-timed, true, meaningful, in line with the teaching and training.

an3.69:13.1.pli: Kasmā cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, evarūpo puggalo vuccati kālavādītipi, bhūtavādītipi, atthavādītipi, dhammavādītipi, vinayavādītipi?

an3.69:13.2.pli: Tathāhāyaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalo na parassa asatā dukkhaṃ uppādayati vadhena vā bandhanena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā pabbājanāya vā balavamhi balattho itipi.
an3.69:13.2.eng: This individual doesn’t cause another to suffer under a false pretext—by execution or imprisonment or confiscation or condemnation or banishment—thinking ‘I’m powerful, I want power’.

an3.69:13.3.pli: Bhūtena kho pana vuccamāno paṭijānāti no avajānāti;
an3.69:13.3.eng: So when someone makes a valid criticism, they admit it and aren’t scornful.

an3.69:13.4.pli: abhūtena vuccamāno ātappaṃ karoti tassa nibbeṭhanāya:
an3.69:13.4.eng: When someone makes a baseless criticism, they make an effort to explain,

an3.69:13.5.eng: ‘This is why that’s untrue, this is why that’s false.’

an3.69:13.6.pli: Tasmā evarūpo puggalo vuccati kālavādītipi, atthavādītipi, dhammavādītipi, vinayavādītipi.
an3.69:13.6.eng: That’s why such an individual is said to have speech that’s well-timed, true, meaningful, in line with the teaching and training.

an3.69:14.1.pli: Evarūpassa, bhikkhave, puggalassa lobhajā pāpakā akusalā dhammā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
an3.69:14.1.eng: For such an individual, bad unskillful qualities born of greed, hate, and delusion are cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

an3.69:14.2.pli: Diṭṭheva dhamme sukhaṃ viharati avighātaṃ anupāyāsaṃ apariḷāhaṃ.
an3.69:14.2.eng: In this very life they’re happy, free of distress, anguish, and fever,

an3.69:14.3.eng: and they’re also extinguished in this very life.

an3.69:15.5.pli: Seyyathāpi bhikkhave, sālo vā dhavo vā phandano vā tīhi māluvālatāhi uddhasto pariyonaddho.
an3.69:15.5.eng: Suppose a sal, axlewood, or boxwood tree was choked and engulfed by three camel’s foot creepers.

an3.69:15.6.eng: Then along comes a person with a spade and basket.

an3.69:15.7.pli: So taṃ māluvālataṃ mūle chindeyya, mūle chetvā palikhaṇeyya, palikhaṇitvā mūlāni uddhareyya, antamaso usīranāḷimattānipi.
an3.69:15.7.eng: They’d cut the creeper out by the roots, dig them up, and pull them out, down to the fibers and stems.

an3.69:15.8.pli: So taṃ māluvālataṃ khaṇḍākhaṇḍikaṃ chindeyya, khaṇḍākhaṇḍikaṃ chetvā phāleyya, phāletvā sakalikaṃ sakalikaṃ kareyya, sakalikaṃ sakalikaṃ karitvā vātātape visoseyya, vātātape visosetvā agginā ḍaheyya, agginā ḍahitvā masiṃ kareyya, masiṃ karitvā mahāvāte vā ophuṇeyya nadiyā vā sīghasotāya pavāheyya.
an3.69:15.8.eng: Then they’d split the creeper apart, cut up the parts, and chop it into splinters. They’d dry the splinters in the wind and sun, burn them with fire, and reduce them to ashes. Then they’d whisk away the ashes in a strong wind, or glide them down a swift stream.

an3.69:15.9.pli: Evamassa tā, bhikkhave, māluvālatā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
an3.69:15.9.eng: So those camel’s foot creepers would be cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, and obliterated, unable to arise in the future.

an3.69:15.10.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, evarūpassa puggalassa lobhajā pāpakā akusalā dhammā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
an3.69:15.10.eng: In the same way, for such an individual, bad unskillful qualities born of greed, hate, and delusion are cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

an3.69:15.11.pli: Diṭṭheva dhamme sukhaṃ viharati avighātaṃ anupāyāsaṃ apariḷāhaṃ.
an3.69:15.11.eng: In this very life they’re happy, free of  distress, anguish, and fever,

an3.69:15.12.eng: and they’re also extinguished in this very life.

an3.69:16.2.pli: mohajā pāpakā akusalā dhammā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.

an3.69:16.3.pli: Diṭṭheva dhamme sukhaṃ viharati avighātaṃ anupāyāsaṃ apariḷāhaṃ.

an3.69:16.5.eng: These are the three skillful roots.”

an3.7:1.1.eng: “A fool is known by three things.

an3.7:1.3.pli: Sāvajjena kāyakammena, sāvajjena vacīkammena, sāvajjena manokammena …pe… anavajjena kāyakammena, anavajjena vacīkammena, anavajjena manokammena …pe….
an3.7:1.3.eng: Blameworthy deeds by way of body, speech, and mind. … An astute person is known by blameless deeds by way of body, speech, and mind. …”
